*La La Land* puts a fair proportion of its energies into creating a dreamlike fantasy version of Los Angeles - a 'city of stars' where anything is possible and dreams can come true. In a way it's attempting to steal the 'city of dreams' identity from New York, traditionally the cultural focus for 'dreams can come true' movie narratives, from the Follies of the 30s to *New York New York* and *Fame*.
*Rebel Without A Cause* is significant in that it was one of the first popular movies to focus on the social problems of Los Angeles - to 'expose' the real disfunctional undertones of the city that houses the superficial glamour of Hollywood. Since then movies that have been set in LA and in and around Hollywood have tended to follow this 'expose the underbelly' pattern, from *Sunset Boulevard* through *Day Of The Locust* and *The Player* all the way to the recent *Inherent Vice* (and incuding films that focus on LA gang conflict such as *Boyz N The Hood*, which are direct descendents of *Rebel Without A Cause*).
Chazelle wants us to forget about all that - to forget this popular LA mythology ever existed. And so Mia and Sebastian choose to see *Rebel Without A Cause* - but Chazelle keeps first us, and then them from really taking the film in in any significant way. Mia first stands in front of the screen, obliterating it from our view, and then the film burns out, preventing the characters from seeing it out to its depressing conclusion. Chazelle includes *Rebel Without A Cause*, and then does everything he can to obliterate it.
What does Chazelle *not* want us to see? *Rebel* ends with the murder of a young man on the steps of the observatory - a sad wasteful event born of street violence - an early example of an event that is a fairly regular occurance on the streets of LA even today. When the police cars have gone, a man in a suit casually walks across the scene, a 'respectable' middle class gent, comletely oblivious to the murder the location has just witnessed. The message is *this is happening around us, we just don't see it*. Mia and Sebastian may idolise James Dean as a glossy movie icon, but within the rhetoric of *La La Land*, the lovers function in every way in the manner of that respectable gent casually walking by the observatory steps. In fact they take his purpose several steps further - gleefully singing and dancing on the grave of *Rebel*'s troubled young hoodlum, just as *La La Land* itself dances on the graves of all the victims of social deprivation, the addicts, the drop outs, the porn stars and the hookers that people a city that has more commonly been presented to us a global heart of darkness. Hi I've been following this thread and although I'm not on your side (sorry!) I think it's cool that you are arguing LLL's corner without getting angry about it, as many do when discussing this film. I also thought Birdman was far from perfect so we can be friends about that later (!).
For me, however, the positive points you make about LLL's structure and writing - groundwork for characters being laid before they appear; thematic motifs returning throughout; environment used as a symbol of the central characters inner life - are really just observations on some very basic narrative devices. These are things movies are *supposed* to do - they are very basic starting points! I think that those of us who didn't rate the film very highly are looking for more, dare I say 'deeper' content. I would stress here that this only applies to LLL because of its rapturous reception by many critics, audiences, and awards ceremonies. If LLL were just another fun movie these discussions wouldn't be happening.
As for the music being memorable, yes I think it *is* a significant point. I remember very well music from the last 20 years! Even if we don't compare LLL to 'the greats' like Singin In The Rain, I remember (in all seriousness) much of the music in, for example, the Southpark movie. Southpark was, in my opinion, an excellent movie musical, and I could sing you bits and pieces of the score right now. I also have a vague recollection of some of the songs in The Muppets (2011). Particularly in the case of Southpark, I would also argue that the songs functioned far better in terms of story telling than those in LLL, often occurring when a character or situation was going through some kind of transition - they moved the story on basically, and were not simply incidental comments on the narrative as I felt they were in LLL (with the exception possibly of Emma Stone's audition song which was transitional). Comparing both film's opening songs, which in the tradition of musicals are intended to establish a sense of location, I would argue Southpark's 'Mountain Town' functions far better than 'Another Day Of Sun', quite brilliantly introducing the town and setting the scene for the action to come, while at the same time introducing the major characters. Frankly, I had *no idea* what on earth the performers in 'Another Day Of Sun' were singing about (I couldn't make out the lyrics!) and for me the song established absolutely zero!
At the end of the day, there is not that much to say about LLL, and this is the problem. This is nothing to do with it being a 'popular' movie. Even when we avoid comparisons to art house films such as Cemetery Of Splendour, LLL doesn't stand up well. To take Southpark as an example again, this silly and often peurile animated musical had, in fact, quite a serious political subtext which attacked the hypocrisy of political correctness and left leaning liberalism (this is something people rarely comment on - for all its subversion, Southpark has a conservative heart). Take, as another example, the massively popular crowd-pleasing comedy Bridesmaids. This bawdy movie contains a deeply subversive feminist subtext - I could deconstruct it for days! These popular, unchallenging, entertaining mainstream films are, none the less, *about* something! What is LLL *about*?!
My own theory is that LLL was intended simply as a loving homage to Los Angeles, using a template provided by Scorsese's New York New York - a loving homage to New York (I would go so far as to suggest Chazelle *wants* us to make the comparison - I mean *New York New York* - *L.A L.A* - it's in the title!). My ultimate criticism would be, therefore, that I left the cinema without a real feeling of L.A. I wasn't inspired by Chazelle's vision of the city - I didn't feel I knew anything unique about its spirit or its character. From a foreign perspective (I'm not from the US) the choice of jazz and theatre based song to celebrate the spirit of L.A. seemed to make far less sense than Scorsese's use of this music to celebrate New York, a city the rest of the world associates with this kind of music. I suspect Hollywood's embracing and promoting of LLL as a 'great movie' has to do with a sense of loyalty and nostalgia for their home town. A film about L.A. that's simply a shiny happy celebration - that's a rare thing, and after 20 years of PT Anderson cleverly dismantling Hollywood and presenting it to the world as a kind of heart of global darkness, Hollywood is going to grab it with both hands and celebrate this rare note of positivity, perhaps turning a blind eye to the real qualities of the movie itself.

Sometimes you just don't connect with a film artist. It's frustrating (believe me - I *know*) when it's somebody that seems to be universlly adored. Kubrick is, IMO, a difficult artist. Not because his films are particularly clever (although of course they are often very clever), but because his ego is so apparent in his work. His presence can be stifling.
He is admired, I think, for his intellectual rigour, his audacity, and his extraordinary single mindedness. Kubrick pandered to *no-one* - not Hollywood, not his producers, not his actors, not even his audience. He pleased himself, and there is something inspiring about such an uncompromising artist. Basically he has massive balls.
The work itself is often thrillingly dramatic. Kubrick had a great flair for composition, knowing when and where to push an audiences buttons to maximum effect. *The Shining* is a good example of this flair for drama, which at times borders on the theatrical. The theatricality is tempered by his direction of actors, which was punishing - he ground actors into submission by making them repeat a scene so many times they abandoned their ego. The technique worked - there is a style of 'Kubrickian performance', dry, measured, and assured, that is quite distinctive. Of course this combative approach (rather than collaborative) is another sign of the man's overwhelming ego. (There are exceptions in the case of the odd actor Kubrick seemed to genuinely admire - Peter Sellers and Jack Nicholson for example).
He is also greatly admired for technical innovation, to which he was never so beholden that he allowed it overwhelm his story telling. The steady-cam in *The Shining* for example is used as a wonderful story-telling tool - never simply for the admiration of the technology itself.
The downside of Kubrick is his extreme control can feel claustrophobic - it can easily turn the viewer off. In addition it meant that his portfolio was highly hit and miss. He did get things wrong, and such was his overwhelming command that his mistakes translate directly onto the screen. The result is that when he is good he is very very good, but when he is bad he is *rotten*. There are all kinds of reasons for not connecting with Kubrick.

I think that Mamet should just not both write and direct the same projects. My personal view is that he is at heart a theatre artist. His dialogue is inherently theatrical and all his instincts are for theatre. If drama works brilliantly in the theatre there is no guarantee it will easily translate to film - just look at attempts to make great plays into films, like Miller's *The Crucible*, or the more recent *August Osage County*. With *Glengarry* you had a film artist as director who managed to pull off a very successful adaptation - although tbh I'm not really sure exactly why that text worked so well on screen. It had the benefit of probably one of the most talented ensemble casts ever assembled for a movie, all of whom (I think) were well seasoned actors of both stage and screen (not sure if Lemmon had done much on stage) and so knew well how to make the transition. It was also brilliantly directed by Foley.
Mamet's stage writing is harsh, often bleak and frequently cruel. This type of writing works well on stage, because there is such an obvious level of unreality, and the audience have some distance on the thing - both physically and emotionally. Often when such writing is put on the big screen the coldness and cruelty is simply too much. Film is so much more of a literal, immersive form; and audience simply can't take it. And so directors often try and soften things. Characters become 'nicer' than their stage versions (this was very true of *August Osage County* - there's just no way a cinema audience could sustain the tragedy and cruelty of that play). When directing his own work, I think Mamet just does not know how to make this transition well. In toning down his own work he loses his way and creates films that lack an identity an audience can really relate to. His characters become strange or even bland.
Probably *Glengarry* works partly because Foley managed to film the action with all of its original venom while somehow keeping the audience on side. I'm wondering if this is partly down to his camera work, which I remember being brilliant in that film. He focuses in on faces when he needs to, but at other times he pulls the camera right back so that we have some distance and can process what's happening without turning off. Sometimes he replaces the physical distance we would experience in the theatre with darkness - we are close, but the darkness gives us some element of protection from what we are witnessing. In addition, Foley and the production designer created a truly cinematic world for the action - the lights - the rain - the trains - it gives the action a context that uses singularly cinematic techniques to tell the story, and greatly helps the transition from a theatrical piece to a filmic one. This is something I have never seen Mamet manage to do on film.

I remember this film vividly as I found it totally absorbing. I think it was a real 'zeitgeist' movie at the time, especially in France. It came at a time when France had just started to wake up to the social problems in its more diverse communities - usually exemplified by the troubled Parisian suburbs. It addressed an older generation's fear of disorder and a lack of respect in younger people, reinforced by the 'otherness' of ethnicity. It's worth remembering that France, while politically and ethically an extremely liberal country, can be culturally very conservative.
The film was also extraordinary in the way it was developed. Based on a book written by a teacher describing his own experiences in a difficult school, the teacher ended up actually *starring* in the film, playing a version of himself (this is the main character). The younger actors were cast directly from similar real life schools, so basically there are almost *no* professional actors in the film. The authenticity this provides is a major feature of the film's success.
The final scene, as I remember, was an optimistic attempt at a happy ending. It suggested that, despite everything, a positive future was possible for both the teacher and the pupils.
If you enjoyed the movie definitely check out Cantet's other films because they are terrific, especially *Time Out* and *Human Resources*.

I agree with you that *2001* is not cold and sterile. The scene where Bowman 'shuts down' HAL is arguably the most open hearted Kubrick has ever been. Of course it's quintessential Kubrick that this sentimental scene portrays the death of the villain of the piece.
I too am a huge admirer of Tarkovsky. But I struggle with *Solaris* - it's the one Tarkovsky film I have seen that made no impact on me at all. Although very generally speaking I would rate Tarkovsky more highly than Kubrick as a film maker, for me personally, out of the two films you mention, *2001* is far and away the more successful. What I struggled with in *Solaris* was the world that Tarkovsky creates. Frankly I just didn't believe it. I completely missed any deeper meanings contained within the narrative, because I just didn't believe the action.
The space craft most of the film is shot on for example - it never seemed more to me than a series of disconnected studio sets. These individual settings bore no relation to each other and, to me, did not appear to be elements of a larger consistent world.
Where Tarkovsky absolutely *floors* me with the sheer beauty of his film making is in his ability to create enchantment. For me this happens suddenly, and springs from the most ordinary, familiar settings. An ordinary kitchen - a half remembered garden - a hotel lobby. It's in these every day settings that Tarkovsky has the ability to create poetry - a sudden, breathtaking magic. A space ship is already fantastic, and so, for me, the enchantment has no foundation.
In addition, I believe Tarkovsky was essentially a poet of his medium. As science fiction, *Solaris* does seem to require, on one level at least, an element of traditional narrative film making. Tarkovsky does not excel in this area, and so for me watching *Solaris* can feel like watching a poet trying to write a detective novel.
These are very personal observations on *Solaris*. I know the film is held in the highest regard by film theorists far more qualified than me, and of course there are likely many aspects of this deeply complexed film I simply missed.

For my two favourite directors - Maurice Pialat and Agnes Varda - casting non-actors in films was a big part of their creative identity. In France in general there is a tradition of this, sometimes leading to overnight stardom for the actor in question. One example that springs to mind was Beatrice Dalle in *Betty Blue*. One of the most extraordinary examples of this I've ever seen was Stefano Cassetti in the 2001 Cedric Kahn film *Roberto Succo*. Apparently Kahn saw Cassetti in a bar and asked him if he wanted to star in his movie. His performance is amazing! As far as I know it was his only engagement as an actor. Homayoun Ershadi in *Taste Of Cherry* is another great example. I think he was working as an architect before Kiarostami cast him..? Now that I start to think of it there are many examples of this kind of casting.
I think in these cases the director must simply be working on pure instinct. There is perhaps also some kind of 'beginners naivety' at work. I think of it as similar to making mayonnaise. The first few times you do it it goes beautifully because you don't know what can go wrong. As soon as you realise how easily it can split, it splits. One of the greatest screen actors of our time, Sandrine Bonnaire, arguably gave her best performances in her first few films when she was still a teen.
As for bad or mediocre actors who are great in a particular role, I can't think of examples of this. I don't think even a great director can transform a bad actor into a great one.

The downside is that the industry can get too obsessed with technology, and the basics of narrative art get pushed into the background. 3D might be an example of this phenomenon. I'm sure HD has added a great deal to cinema on one level, but it's not why people go to the movies or watch them at home.
